text:
I Tried $173 Worth Of Hand Creams & Only One Totally Eradicated My Dry Skin

But considering how much we put our hands and feet through daily, she always drove home how important it is to show them a little extra TLC when possible.Â 

Since then, Iâ€™ve tried my best to follow her example, though itâ€™s difficult for someone with perpetually parched hands, further exacerbated by cold weather and heating. Over the years, Iâ€™ve also learned that not all hand creams are created equal. Most are sticky and donâ€™t bode well for phone screens; others sting (a no-go for chapped knuckles), and some are so thin they donâ€™t do much at all.Â 

Keen to find the â€œGoldilocksâ€ of hand creams â€” essentially the one that ticks all of my boxes â€” I made it my mission to try as many products down to the very last drop over the winter. Some of these hand creams have been recommended by top dermatologists, while others have gone so viral on TikTok that I couldnâ€™t resist trying them out. Fast forward to this month, and I think I mightâ€™ve found the cream of the crop.Â 

Without further ado, read ahead for my honest thoughts on $195 worth of hand creams.

DashDividers_1_500x100

La Roche-Posay Cicaplast Soothing Hand Cream, $12.99

Last year, I was lucky enough to go skincare shopping in Paris with dermatologist Dr. Justine Hextall. There were probably a hundred hand creams lining the shelves of the French pharmacies we visited, but she picked out this fragrance-free version for my very dry skin. Dr. Hextall encouraged me to slather on a generous amount before bed and to pull on a pair of cotton gloves (you could also use a pair of socks!), kind of like a makeshift overnight hand mask. I saw the best results when I used this consistently. Itâ€™s all down to hydrating niacinamide, skin-smoothing shea butter, and a whopping 30% glycerin, a humectant, which draws moisture into the skin. Thanks to dimethicone, a type of silicone, it makes hands feel silky rather than sticky, but itâ€™s quite thick in texture and takes a moment to absorb fully. I ran out of the 50ml version too quickly, so Iâ€™d recommend spending a little bit more on the 100ml tube.Â Â 

Rare Beauty Find Comfort Hydrating Hand Cream, $18

I have to get one gripe out of the way first: The packaging might be â€œspillproof,â€ but it isnâ€™t user-friendly. You have to give this a good squeeze to release the lotion, and even then, itâ€™s pretty difficult to get much out. Iâ€™m not the only one. Countless reviewers say the same, and when your hands are feeling sore, thatâ€™s the last thing you need. Packaging aside, I love the chic scent (thatâ€™ll be creamy jasmine, zippy lemon, and comforting cashmere wood), and the cream softens tight, dry hands without a hint of slipperiness.

Aesop Eleos Aromatique Hand Balm, $35

This is a hand cream first and an aromatherapy treatment second â€” it smells incredible. A few essential oils are behind the soothing scent, so itâ€™s not something Iâ€™d recommend for those with very sore or chapped hands in case of irritation, but itâ€™s still high up on my list. Thatâ€™s because it boasts moisturizing glycerin, softening shea butter, and nourishing castor oil â€” three ingredients that breathe life into my dry, ashy hands. Donâ€™t let that fool you into thinking itâ€™ll leave you with greasy fingertips, though. My hands drink it up quickly, and itâ€™s become my favorite hand cream for on-the-go top-ups. As you can probably tell by the state of this tube, itâ€™s a purse staple.

CeraVe Reparative Hand Cream, $13.49

Iâ€™ve been through multiple tubs of CeraVeâ€™s Moisturizing Cream over the years, but itâ€™s too big to carry around with me. Enter: Reparative Hand Cream. It features the same skin-strengthening ceramides, which act like glue in between skin cells to keep the skin barrier intact and moisture under lock and key. It sinks in fast, too. I looked to this when my hands were cracked and sore, and it helped to heal them quickly, but I found that I needed to layer up throughout the day. Still, itâ€™s more or less traceless â€” and fragrance-free â€” so that didnâ€™t bother me. I just need it to come in a bigger tube.Â 

Lâ€™Occitane Shea Butter Hand Cream, $32

In the past couple of months, Iâ€™ve been through two 150ml tubes of this hand cream; nothing else has eradicated my dry skin quite like it. The star ingredients are 20% shea butter, which moisturizes deeply, and beta-glucan, which experts are championing as the new, more hydrating hyaluronic acid. Not only does this ingredient soothe and soften skin instantly, but itâ€™s known to repair and heal over time. Lâ€™Occitane promises eight hours of intense hydration â€” and I believe it. I apply this before bed, and when I wake up, my hands look brand new. Even when I wash my hands after using it, theyâ€™re still unbelievably soft. Seeing as itâ€™s substantially quenching, it takes about a minute for my hands to soak it up properly, but it works a treat. Dry skin? Donâ€™t know her. This is my number one.Â 

NÃ©cessaire The Hand Cream Barrier Treatment, $28

This absorbs easily and is packed with skin-repairing ceramides, moisturizing glycerin, and quenching shea butter â€” but itâ€™s pricier than other hand creams on this list with very similar properties. For me, the main selling point is that I can use my phone or laptop almost immediately, and because itâ€™s formulated without perfume, it doesnâ€™t tingle or sting when applied to broken skin. I also like that you can squeeze every last drop out of the aluminum tube. Itâ€™s certainly chic, so if you have more to spend, why not?Â 

Aveeno Daily Moisturising Hand Cream, $17.91

If itâ€™s instant relief youâ€™re after, Aveeno has got you covered. This takes all of 30 seconds to disappear into dry hands (I counted), doesnâ€™t leave behind any greasy residue, and makes rough skin feel much softer thanks to moisturizing glycerin and cushiony dimethicone. While it does the job, my dry hands require regular applications throughout the day, especially after washing. All in all, it makes a great desk hand cream for frequent typers.Â 

Sol de Janeiro Brazilian Touch Hand Cream, $16

I thought this hand cream would be all smell, no substance, but Iâ€™m very happy to be proven wrong. With coconut oil, squalane, and sodium hyaluronate (a type of hyaluronic acid), itâ€™s considerably moisturizing and melted into my dry hands almost instantly. For those familiar with the brandâ€™s viral Cheirosa â€™62 fragrance, this hand cream is equally as beachy and sunscreen-y in smell, and the perfume lingered on my skin for a good while â€” even after I washed my hands. I keep this on my desk at home for a mid-afternoon pick-me-up. (It might be a little too potent for the officeâ€¦)

title: In Defense Of Wicked: For Good. Elphaba & Glindaâ€™s Love Story Finds Strength In Its Sincerity
text:
In Defense Of Wicked: For Good. Elphaba & Glindaâ€™s Love Story Finds Strength In Its Sincerity

Spoilers ahead. Thereâ€™s been a lot of talk about the door. If youâ€™ve seen Wicked: For Good, you know exactly which door I mean. During â€œFor Good,â€ the movieâ€™s title track, Cynthia Erivoâ€™s Elphaba and Ariana Grandeâ€™s Glinda dramatically say their goodbyes to each other through a dilapidated barrier, and through tears, of course. At the end of this scene, Glinda and Elphaba exchange three words that â€” until now â€” were forbidden in the world composer Stephen Schwartz created: â€œI love you.â€Â 

The moment, like most things in director Jon M. Chuâ€™s Wicked universe, is devastatingly emotional, maximized to elicit big feelings from the audience, and anchored by two performances that, no matter how saccharine the material, pull the film back down to the ground. If â€œDefying Gravityâ€ was a confrontation between a budding radical and a well-meaning white moderate about how power corrupts and divides, â€œFor Goodâ€ can be read as the reconciliation between two people with different approaches to the same problem: fighting facism. But also, itâ€™s simply about the power of friendship. Itâ€™s about how friendship molds you, how it can be the thing that heals and bonds, and the relationship that reorganizes the molecules in your brain, shifting everything you thought you knew about yourself and the world around you. Friendship is what makes us whole. Itâ€™s what makes us human. And, most importantly, Wicked: For Good is about how Elphaba and Glinda are the great loves of each otherâ€™s lives.Â 

If you didnâ€™t get all that from two witches singing harmonies only celestial beings could hit, maybe Wicked isnâ€™t for you. And thatâ€™s OK. Some of my fellow critics have had harsh reactions to Wicked: For Good. NPRâ€™s headline reads, â€œThis could have all been one movieâ€ and IndieWire writes, â€œFinale of a Needlessly Two-Part Movie MusicalÂ  Adaptation Doesnâ€™t Go Out on a High Note.â€ AP News went with a nod to The Wizard of Oz: â€œsorry, my pretty, â€˜For Goodâ€™ doesnâ€™t delight.â€ The Atlantic: â€œWicked: For Good Bursts Its Own Bubble.â€ The New Yorkerâ€™s review by Justin Chang is the most ruthless, calling the movie â€œvery, very badâ€ while chiding its â€œdreadful filmmaking.â€ Every one of these reviews make some fair points about the clunky inclusion of Dorothy, her cohort, and the effectiveness of Wicked as a prequel to The Wizard of Oz, but most of these critics didnâ€™t like the first one either. And since, famously, part two of the musical has never been revered as highly as part one, those reactions were inevitable. But what so many of these detractors see as Wicked: For Goodâ€™s weaknesses â€” its sincerity, optimistic politics, tidy resolutions, and feel-good messaging â€” are actually its strengths.Â 

In a time when everyoneâ€™s a critic but no oneâ€™s an expert (an Amazon mic and a TikTok account do not a specialist make) and when standom has made it nearly impossible to share a dissenting opinion without heaps of hate, doxxing, and backlash, Iâ€™m never going to knock well-written, thoughtful criticism (even if I think some of these reviews are written by men who just donâ€™t like musicals, or women emoting). But I can disagree. And I donâ€™t think Wicked: For Good is a disappointment. Itâ€™s a pretty faithful adaptation of the second act of an ambitious musical that aims to please. The changes from the Broadway musical to the big screen (like giving Glinda more depth and making Nessaroseâ€™s arc less ableist) absolutely work to make the narrative more cohesive, modern, and to deliver satisfying moments that make sure moviegoers get their moneyâ€™s worth.Â 

One of those moments is â€œFor Good,â€ the musical number weâ€™ve waited a whole year for. Erivo and Grande have gotten flack for their joint press interviews that people perceive as codependent, cloying, and overly emotional. But once you see these two sing â€œWho can say if Iâ€™ve been/ changed for the better/ But because I knew you/ I have been changed for goodâ€ it starts to make sense. First of all, they are theater kids. Being overly emotional is their whole thing. Also, itâ€™s refreshing to see two performers care so deeply about their work that they canâ€™t help but cry about it. Iâ€™d take this energy over indifference any day. To hear Grande and Erivo tell it, the parallels between their friendship and the one we see on screen are vast, and since theyâ€™ve been sitting with this material for years, theyâ€™ve developed a bond that formed long before they locked fingers in a junket while holding space for the lyrics of â€œDefying Gravity.â€ And once you are sitting in the theater locked in on the culmination of Elphaba and Glindaâ€™s saga, youâ€™ll forget about the off-camera speculation and public perceptions and drift away to Oz to be serenaded by the Wicked Witch of the West and Glinda The Good who have, against all odds, found their way back to each other.Â 

By the time we get to â€œFor Goodâ€ in the film, Elphaba has been living in hiding attempting to expose the Wizardâ€™s lies. Sheâ€™s on a quest to free Ozâ€™s animals who have been stripped of their voices and their rights. Her image (caricature posters depicting her with exaggerated features are so comically evil, they are reminiscent of Jim Crow-era, anti-Black imagery) is projected all over Oz as a symbol of hate and villainy. Conversely, Glinda has everything sheâ€™s ever wanted â€” sheâ€™s risen to fame as a beloved symbol of Goodness â€” but still doesnâ€™t have any magic of her own. With the help of Madame Morrible (a consistently uneven Michelle Yeoh), sheâ€™s keeping up illusions to maintain the Wizardâ€™s tyrannical rule. Glinda is literally living in a bubble to upkeep the lies. Sheâ€™s everything Elphaba warned her of becoming in â€œDefying Gravity.â€ Glinda is about to marry Fiyero (played perfectly by Sexiest Man Alive, Jonathan Bailey), now the captain of the Wizardâ€™s guard, who hasnâ€™t stopped his search for his real love, Elphaba.Â 

It would be easy to read the dynamic between Elphaba, Fiyero and Glinda as just another literary love triangle, with two girls torn between a dashing prince, but as charming and hot as Fiyero is (I broke into a sweat during the chaste yet horny â€œAs Long As Youâ€™re Mineâ€), heâ€™s really not that important. While itâ€™s beautiful to see Elphaba find the romantic love she deserves, and the origin story of the Scaregrow is the strongest part of the Wizard of Oz tie-in, Fiyero mainly exists as a test of Glinda and Elphabaâ€™s friendship. On her wedding day, Glinda has to process the fact that her ex-best friend and her fiancÃ© are about to run away together. The tables have turned and now, she is Not That Girl. Glinda has lived a privileged life as the popular girl, always chosen, always winning, and always sheltered from having to make any hard choices. Sheâ€™s the girl who gets to walk down the aisle while Elphaba marches into the Wizardâ€™s dungeon to free wrongfully imprisoned animals. (The gutting juxtaposition of these scenes, and how beautifully the sequence can be interpreted to show the paradox of white frivolity versus the responsibilities unfairly placed on marginalized people is why they can never make me hate Jon M. Chu.) Now, Glinda has not only lost her groom, but the bubble she so carefully constructed is also about to burst. Later, when Fiyero risks his life to save Elphaba by pointing a gun at Glindaâ€™s face, you see her accept his love for Elphaba and her own. She calls his bluff, and resigns herself to the fact that they both love Elphaba. Of course they do. GrandÃ© is heartbreakingly magnificent in this moment, playing Glindaâ€™s conflict with painful awareness.Â 

Itâ€™s clear that Wicked: For GoodÂ  is invested in Glindaâ€™s redemption. She goes from self-serving mean girl to the arbiter of all things good. Itâ€™s fun to watch this transformation unfold, thanks in large part to Grandeâ€™s performance, but itâ€™s also a fairytale without a happily ever after (I like her but I still think Glinda is a spineless, complicit, mediocre fraud who ainâ€™t shit). We know in real life that opportunists rarely change their tune, that white women who turn their backs on their Black (ahem, green) counterparts for their own self interests do so callously and with gleeful disregard for their humanity. But in a world of talking Tin Men and cowardly lions, why canâ€™t the fantasy include the moral salvation of the girl who â€œgroveled in submission/ to feed [her] own ambitionâ€? Itâ€™s a nice story, even though it comes at the expense of Elphabaâ€™s freedom.

If I have one major critique of Wicked: For Good, itâ€™s that I wanted more for my girl Elphaba. Itâ€™s hard to watch her fall on her sword as Glinda gets the glory. Dorothy is now in Oz, after allegedly murdering Nessarose by way of a falling house (we later learn it was Madame Morrible who did the deed, inspired by a Glinda suggestion). Elphaba decides that Oz needs a villain, a foe to Glindaâ€™s hero, and offers herself up as the symbol they need to shun. Sheâ€™s made this decision out of hurt and frustration â€” Fiyero is arrested and would have been beaten to death if Elphaba didnâ€™t cast a spell turning his bones into straw â€” and is done doing good deeds with zero reward.Â 

Many headlines about Wicked: For Good have focused on Grande, and while itâ€™s true she is great in this sequel and that itâ€™s more Glindaâ€™s movie than Elphabaâ€™s, Erivo is still firing on all cylinders, delivering a timeless performance that is also worthy of unadulterated praise. Throughout Wicked: For Good, Elphaba goes from fugitive freedom fighter, to heartbroken friend and exasperated sister, to frustrated revolutionary, to lover in mourning, to resigned martyr. Itâ€™s a depressing arc that sees the optimism of progressivism dashed with a big dose of witch-melting water. The simplicity of the message â€” that doing good comes at a cost, that no matter your intentions, things donâ€™t always work in your favor, and that facism may take on a new face but itâ€™s an ever-present threat â€” is the point. No one is fully good nor evil. In systems set up to oppress, the binary of good vs. evil is just another tool of the oppressor. While I donâ€™t love the optics of a Black woman (weâ€™ve established that Elphaba is Black) giving up her freedom and her reputation to save a white woman who betrayed her once and a population who vilified her, the lesson is about who you are when the choice is to do good without any benefit to yourself at all. How much goodness can you muster when it would be easier to be seduced by evil? Who are you in your darkest moments? What are your values, really?

In Changâ€™s New Yorker review, he references Gregory Maguireâ€™s novel the Broadway musical is loosely based on, which was an adaptation of Frank L. Baumâ€™s childrenâ€™s book, The Wonderful Wizard of Oz: â€œMaguireâ€™s novel was itself written in the spirit of a corrective; it aimed to bring a morally ambiguous modernism and a grownup, forthright sexuality to bear on Baumâ€™s squeaky-clean demarcations of good and evil.â€ Itâ€™s true that Wicked: For Goodâ€™s political commentary may be clumsy at times and very much watered down from its source material (the characters are less overtly queer and some are literally whitewashed), but the musical still aims to take a stand against totalitarianism and teach audiences that a lying dictatorship uninterested in the truth and wielding power without checks and balances is bad, actually. And right now, I think thatâ€™s good, actually.Â 

I understand the critiques, but letâ€™s take the Wicked movies for what they are instead of what you hoped the stage musical would be. The movies were never going to be a radical reimagining of Maguireâ€™s novel because thatâ€™s not what the musical is. Itâ€™s a big-hearted, campy, bold, funny, entertaining ride with a strong message.Â 

Again, ultimately, Wicked is about Elphaba and Glinda, two girls who grew together while figuring themselves out. Itâ€™s about the complexity, softness, and intensity of platonic affection. Itâ€™s about how all-consuming female friendship can be in your youth. And itâ€™s about the door (the â€œI love yousâ€ were improvised, Erivo says). Thereâ€™s always been a chasm between the two witches â€” one is unusually and exceedingly peculiar and altogether quite impossible to describe, the other is blonde â€” and as they finally reach their farewell, the realization that they are better off because of their relationship hits, and it all coalesces in a gut wrenching declaration of mutual adoration, respect, and forgiveness. The fact that there is still a door between them in this moment, a physical divide between them as they grow into their most actualized selves, is exactly the ending these two characters should have, no matter how bittersweet.Â 

Itâ€™s up for debate if Glinda and Elphaba ever see each other again, or if Glinda even knows her best friend is alive and wandering beyond the walls of Oz journeying to a new life with Fiyero (I think the answer is yes). In the Wicked cinematic universe, itâ€™s also left unclear as to what kind of leader Glinda The Good becomes. In the absence of her evil overlords, does Glinda live up to the task Elphaba entrusts her with? Does she stay true to the final speech she gives to her fellow Ozians? Does she become who her best friend believed she could be? Thereâ€™s hope in each of these questions. And when you look at it all through Elphabaâ€™s eyes â€” the ones that saw the Good in Glinda before she did â€” itâ€™s enough to move even the most cynical viewer. Even if you arenâ€™t sobbing in the theater like I was, I promise if you open your heart, let go and embrace its earnestness, Wicked: For Good will change something in you for the better.Â

When it comes to beauty, Korea is in a league of its own. Glass skin wasnâ€™t created by accident; itâ€™s all about careful, consistent care. This time, itâ€™s treatments. Enter: hairline microblading.

Even if hairline microblading is completely new to you, Iâ€™m willing to bet youâ€™ve at least heard of brow microblading. You probably know someone who swears by it. The semi-permanent makeup treatment is famous worldwide for using tiny needles and natural-tone pigments to mimic fine brow hairs, essentially filling in sparse patches. Some microblading technicians can even create an entire brow from scratch.Â

Considering its ability to transform a face, it was only a matter of time before microblading made its way to the scalp. If Koreaâ€™s hair experts are anything to go by, itâ€™s an excellent way to boost a thinning hairline quickly and effectively, outperforming tedious (and often questionable) hair growth serums.

Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about hairline microblading â€” and how to make it work for you.

First of all, what causes a thinning hairline?

Eva Proudman FIT IAT, a leading consultant trichologist, says the hairline is the only place on our bodies that retains â€˜babyâ€™ or vellus hairs â€” essentially finer, wispier strands â€” so shedding there can appear more noticeable. A handful of factors can trigger hair shedding, also known as telogen effluvium. Think: hormonal shifts, stress, illness, weight loss, certain medications, and even high-tension hairstyles, like slicked-back buns or tight ponytails.Â 

What is hairline microblading, and what are the benefits?

Among professionals, hairline microblading is commonly referred to as scalp micropigmentation (SMP), says Proudman, who recommends it in the right circumstances. â€œIt involves medical tattoos being applied to the scalp as small dots to give the illusion of follicles and hair.â€ Hairline microblading can be effective for certain types of thinning and hair loss, adds Proudman, and itâ€™s often used to disguise small areas rather than provide full coverage â€” but not everyone is qualified to perform it.

Karen Betts, an authority in permanent makeup treatments and founder of Karen Betts Clinics, says hairline microblading requires a highly experienced hand. â€œBrow hairs are shorter, coarser, and more structured, but hairline hairs around the temples grow more sparsely and lie flatter,â€ she explains. As such, hairline strokes need to be softer, more diffused, and carefully placed to blend seamlessly with existing hair, adds Betts. Thanks to ultra-fine needles, itâ€™s now easier to replicate fine hairs with ink, but itâ€™s still essential to choose a practitioner whoâ€™s properly qualified in scalp microblading.Â

What are the risks or challenges associated with hairline microblading?

If TikTok is anything to go by, hairline microblading might seem like a miracle solution for those experiencing thinning, but itâ€™s not without its downsides. Firstly, your skin type matters. Betts explains that some people have thinner scalp skin than others, which requires a much lighter touch to avoid irritation or tattooing too deeply â€” again, why itâ€™s important to go to someone qualified to work on the scalp and who knows their stuff.Â 

If your scalp tends to be oilier, this can blur the pigment, adds Betts, making hair strokes appear unnatural and affecting how long they last. Then thereâ€™s the color choice and stroke direction, all of which matter for seamless, natural results. Betts adds that for clients with darker skin tones, there may not be enough contrast between the pigment and the skin to show fine detail. â€œIn these cases, the effect will look more like shading rather than distinct hair strokes,â€ she says.Â 

Proudman warns that, like brows, the hairline is very visible. â€œGetting something that is too heavy or obvious, or sits below the natural hairline, is simply not a good idea, and you may come to regret it,â€ she says. Ultimately, hairline microblading should be a collaborative process with your chosen artist. â€œIf thereâ€™s any uncertainty about how the skin will take the pigment, itâ€™s wise to do a test area first to see how the color holds,â€ says Betts. â€œPigment may also fade unevenly if the strokes arenâ€™t applied carefully,â€ she adds. Betts emphasizes the importance of choosing a qualified professional and says itâ€™s all about patience and restraint, enhancing the hairline in a subtle way, rather than trying to completely transform it.

How does hairline microblading compare to hair growth treatments like minoxidil?

While hairline microblading is popping off on TikTok, Betts isnâ€™t entirely sure the trend will stick around.
